page.title: 05SILAGING IN PLAISH,SHROPS.
page.content: Silaging is a means of conserving grass for use as winter feed for sheep and cattle. It starts at the beginning of April when Ammonium Nitrate is applied to the young grass to promote quick growth. About 8 weeks later we cut with a 2.5 metre mower; this machine also passes the grass through 2 rubber rollers which bruise it to allow it to wilt faster. The crop is then left for 24 hours to create a dry matter content of around 35% A baler is used to make a cylinder-shaped bale 1.6m long x 1m wide. The completed bales are very dense and weigh about 350kg each. They are then taken for stacking where each one is placed in individual air-tight plastic bags. Fermentation takes 8 weeks and the silage is then ready for use.
